content_1: . An outbreak of H1N1 influenza began on August 23 on a fattening farm in Länsi- ja Sisä-Suomi. Of the farm’s 1,500 pigs, 150 showed symptoms such as sneezing, coughing, fever, and loss of appetite. Testing by the Finnish Food Safety Authority showed that H1N1 was the cause of illness. Officials are controlling the movement of swine within the country and screening animals to prevent the spread of the disease. It is not known how the pigs became infected with the disease.
content_2: . Starting on August 27, many chickens in a village in Aceh province died suddenly. Further investigation by Participatory Disease Surveillance and Response (PDSR), Agriculture of Livestock Service West Aceh has confirmed that those chickens died from H5N1 bird flu. The dead chickens have been burned and buried and the remaining chickens have been culled to prevent the spread of the disease.
